text:
Out of NPAC’S first 18 months’ experiences and
the conclusions of the National Agricultural Com¬
munications Conference, four major areas emerge as
the principal targets of the NPAC program. Each
specific activity undertaken by NPAC classifies into
one or more of these areas, as follows:
Professional Improvement of Agricultural Corn-
Operations here are designed to help
individuals, institutions, organizations, or communica¬
tion media obtain or extend pre-service and in-service
training opportunities in agricultural communications.
This includes ways to encourage or recruit more peo¬
ple for the profession and to cooperate with efforts
to improve preparation of students for communica¬
tion careers in agriculture.
Cooperation in Agricultural Communications.
Efforts here are directed toward helping everyone
concerned achieve an effective, efficient educational
job through full cooperation of educational institu¬
tions, communications media, agricultural industries,
and farm organizations.
Integration and Administration of Communica-
Activities here are such as to enable admin¬
istrators, specialists, editors, and others to determine
where and how the communications operation can
best serve both the institution or organization and the
specific public or audience.
Main objectives
here are to help communicators and educators deter¬
mine ways to assess the needs of people, to key com¬
munications to those needs, and to evaluate results.
This includes efforts to inventory, make known and
encourage application of research findings related to
agricultural communications, as well as to help gain
further insight into the communication process
through new research.
